We just came back from the Bay Cruise and a 5 mile walk to the Pier so we were starving.

service:  pretty good, but our food took a long long time to come out and I saw servers B.S.'ing with each other and talking about what they were going to do that night......

food:  My wife the Crab Sandwich and fries.    She really liked the soft roll it was served on, and she said the crab tasted fresh.   $18
I had the California Burger, which was mediocre.  ( not their forte, I know )  $12

drinks:  They have Pilsner Urquiel on tap...niiiice!!!!!    $7

note:  the unisex bathroom is filthy as hell.  Wastebasket overflowing with paper towels and who knows what, sink clogged, toilet only suited for Number 1.  Seriously, I would marinade in a porto potty before this hellish little room.

Overall, I say

MEH.
author: Vik S.

description:
I think the Eagle suffers from having a built-in clientel. Since it's located smack dab in the middle of the most touristy part of the city, it doesn't really need to work about keeping regulars or maintaining repeat business. That's why it's so hit-and-miss. I work near this place so I've been a few times for lunch. I like the atmosphere, very light and airy. I like the menu. The prices are pretty steep, but you are paying for a huge pile of food no matter what you order. I'd rather have half the portion and pay a few bucks less... but America likes big food, and that's what they get at the Eagle. Actually the best value on the menu is the Cobb salad which is about $13 and is a trough of meats, cheese, egg and incidental veggie things. Pretty good really.

The last time I was there wasn't a great experience however. My GF and I went in for a light lunch, so we shared a salad and garlic bread. It took 25 minutes for the cold floppy garlic bread to arrive, and when we asked about our salad, the waitresses' response immediately was "Well, I put the order in right after I took it, I don't know why it's taking so long." It sounded very guilty, and the obvious subtext was that she had actually forgotten our order. Then, after another 10 minutres (how long does it take to cook a cold salad?) We asked a gain about the salad, saying it would be good to have the garlic bread and salad together. We received a cold response, and then a few minutes later our waitress dropped the salad on our table and remarked "There, now you have them together, happy?"

Wow, yes we are happy now, because you just saved us having to leave a tip.
author: Jesse C.

description: Went here for lunch while on vacation. I didnt have any problems with the place. The food was pretty good, probably a little overpriced. The salad I got was huge and very good, the soup was average.
author: Katie S.

description: Just left here feeling completely ripped off. Everything took forever (including glasses of water) and the cocktails were expensive and weak. Really ruined the mood for a nice night out in SF with my husband. The view is great, but not worth the terrible service and mediocre (at best) food.
author: Gwen C.

description: Went in for drinks and a quick bite to break up the afternoon while visiting SF in September. Our server Michell was very attentive and we had a great seat overlooking the pier where sea lions / seals were frolicking in the water (yes, I just used the word frolicking). The dirty martini's were good, if a bit on the small and a LOT on the expensive side. The crab melt was absolutely to die for!
author: Kris A.

description: I went on a Monday night and the pier was very dead which was fine with me. I started off with 6 oysters which where opened and prepared right in front of me. The oyster where delicious and fresh. I had their clam chowder in their sourdough bread bowl and it was absolutely delicious, it didn't leave you feeling heavy afterwards. Their strawberries and cream dessert was also quite delicious. What really made the experience great was the friendly service from the bartender. I would definitely visit again.
author: Eliana A.

description: Love the crab Benedict! Love the rich history of this place-it's been around since 1928! Great views on the pier. Mario the manager is always very attentive and friendly. He's been working at this restaurant for over 30 years starting out in the kitchen. Enjoy talking to him! I live nearby and love bringing my out of town guests here.
author: Tami C.

description:
So while I live like 3 blocks from Fisherman's Wharf, I think any local avoids the touristo areas at all costs...

Saw that this place had good bloodies and since we were too cold to sit outside nextdoor in the shade (also great bloody reviews, for sweeties), we came here and fought the crowds of tourists and SEVERE winds the lovely wharf always has to offer...

As always, menus blew away when we tried to sit outside, so sat at the bar...bloody was fairly good (by SF standards, definitely good, by NOLA standards, average), and $8 which is pretty fair at a tourist trap like this (at the end of pier 39)...was fairly vacant, but from the menu i saw they had regular oyster shooters for $3 (which i'd do if i didnt already know butterfly does $1 oyster shooters for hh), and $7 oyster shooters with vodka (was tempted, but didnt)...

they also had a bloody with crab that i'd seen online (bloodies were removed from their drink menu altogether), which i believe is like $18, that i'd love to try...but probably wont be back just b/c i despite fishermans wharf...but this place was low key and definitely worth stopping by IF youre in the area and looking for somewhere not swarming with annoying tourists...
author: Danielle J.

description: Expensive, very limited choice of barely average quality of food.
author: Iryna B.

description: The first time we ate at Eagle Cafe was July 2010 when we visited San Francisco for our first time. We ate breakfast at the Eagle Cafe one morning and we were blown away with the service and quality of our meals. Two years later......we went back to San Francisco and decided to go back to Eagle Cafe yet again.....I can say that it is a great place to eat!!  The view is lovely, the breakfast portions are crazy big and the service was just as good the second time around. In fact, we had Shannon as our server this past time as well as two years prior.  Shannon you do a great job and we were pleased to have you as our server again. Keep up the great job! Should we find ourselves visiting San Fran again, we will no doubt return to the Eagle Cafe.
author: Claudia B.

description: First things first- 1 star is too good for this place. They were out of oysters, pasta with red sauce, and bread was cold. The butter was frozen and the bread was cold so we asked our waiter if he could bring us some warm bread . Instead we were brought another plate of cold bread. The waiter told us this is the warmest bread they have. Guess they have never heard of a bread warmer/microwave. I ordered the stuffed prawns AND THEY WERE ACTUALLY HOT! However the shrimps were not peeled. Try peeling the skin off of a super hot shrimp. The waiter was extremely inattentive and more concerned with hanging by the front door and talking to girls. He forgot to discount our check 10% with our yelp coupon so I had to remind him to do that. Food is WAY OVER price and lacks original flavor. The only thing good about this place was that we were seated  immediately. But this should have been our first clue that things were not right since all the other restaurants had waiting times.
author: Reisha B.

description: Just gotta love this place - fresh seafood and good drinks in a laid-back atmosphere that doesn't pretend to be upscale like many of the places surrounding it.  You'll forget you are in a major tourist spot and feel like you're eating at a local SF place.
author: Rob J.

description: We were here early October. Had the happy hour half price oysters and drinks. We sat at the bar. The oysters were delicious. They even had fresh grated horseradish. Service was excellent. We definitely be back for happy hours oysters and beer. Well worth the price.
author: Will C.

description:
My wife and I are visiting the area we are two young boys.  We had breakfast at Eagle Cafe yesterday morning.  Good food, good location but the service was subpar.  My wife and I each ordered a Vegi omelette. I ordered mine without mushrooms but the waiter seemed a little confused and thought I asked for mushrooms at first.  My wife asked for her omelette with cheese or mushrooms.  My food came to order but my wife got her order with cheese.
When she mentioned this to the waiter, his reaction was very defensive and he said he thought my wife said "with cheese".  First,  why would she request cheese for an order that originally includes cheese??  Second, I've never seen a server argue with a customer.  He seemed very overwhelmed but I would think its wrong to question a customer. He did return and tried to offer to take my wife's order back but by then she had scraped off the cheese and didn't want to deal with him anymore.
On the flip side of service, the manager was kind enough to bring our toddler some toast before the rest of us got our meal as he was being a little feisty.
Still, I've never had a waiter argue with us and was very turned off.  Once again, good food, good location but beware of the combative waiter there.
author: Mike S.

description: I know this sounds nuts but we love taking a walk to this touristy fisher mans wharf on Wednesday mornings when it is not so touristy and having an amazing breakfast at the Eagle. I have tried everything on the menu and the best is the strawberry pancakes. And the coffee is even better than Starbucks! We get there early th watch the morning waves through the huge windows. Love it
author: Dr Judith N.

description: Had breakfast last Sunday and the food is perfect...  have been before and will keep going back.  The food is good and the people are even better.  Thanks and a perfect Sunday morning.  Lyn M.
author: Lyn M.

description: Lobster Bisque was great! Fried calamari was good as well. service was on point and i'll definately stop at this place again in the future.
author: Jason V.

description:
After a long ride in the rain across the Golden Gate Bridge to Sausalito we were looking forward to some clam chowder in a sourdough bread bowl. The friends who were with us were visiting from the UK and what is more San Francisco than clam chowder in a bread bowl?

Imagine then how disappointed we all were when were told upon ordering that they were out of bread bowls. We waited for the waiter to make some concessions for other things he could do to make up for it but there was nothing. We had already ordered drinks and were so tired and hungry that we just couldn't be bothered to move, but had we been told at the start that they were out of key ingredient of what I expect is one of their popular items (like they do in most restaurants) we would have appreciated it and had a much better outlook on this place even if we decided to stay.

So with no bread bowls we settled on regular bowls of clam chowder, some fried calamari and some oysters. The hubs said the oysters were really good, me not being a huge fan cannot vouch for them but they seemed to be reasonably priced. The calamari was good but as long as it's not rubber fried calamari usually is.

The clam chowder was okay. I think there were green peppers in it which was kind of unusual but overall the taste was fine. To be fair I had been really looking forward to my bread bowl so unless it was knock your socks of good, which is wasn't, I was bound to be disappointed.

The service was decent, the guy tried to be funny, but he his humor just couldn't make up for everything not to mention his disappearance for about 20 minutes while we were waiting for the bill. Next time we'll hit up Boudin.
author: Cindy N.

description:
IT WAS HELLA GOOD...

As I walked up to Pier 39, I realized that I was craving some Claim Chowder (plus it was 51 degrees and I needed to warm up).  We walked into the first place that didn't have a line and found the Eagle Cafe.  We didn't have to wait long for a table but HOPEFULLY, you don't need to go to the bathroom.  I stood in line for 30 mins just to get into a unisex bathroom!

I ordered a bowl of Claim Chowder and an order of crab melt.  It took 30 mins for the crab melt to come out and 45 mins for the Claim Chowder.  I was thinking, "wow, this better be good!"  Sadly, it was nothing phenomenal!  No wonder there was no line!  

Besides the view and friendly service, I would suggest just waiting in line for a better restaurant!
author: Hula R.

description: Food was really good. Corner beef has was great. Big potions.
author: Jess P.

description:
On my way to San Francisco, my goal was to see Lombard St, go on Wine Tour and have clam chowder. All the tour guides said I should go and stop by Eagle Cafe because the food was great and they have a long reputation of shelling out great food. And by gum they were right. The clam chowder was creamy and mesmirizing. I added some more Tabasco sauce to add a little heat, but it's great without it. I had the bowl because the cup option was rather small for my big lady appetite. In hindsight, I should've gotten the clam chowder by itself and not order and plate of chicken tenders. I was overzealous. It didn't help that there were these Australian tourist sitting next to me, all agog at the lady eating herself to death.
Oh course I didn't die, I actually doggie bagged my chicken tenders and gave it to a woman by the piers. I probably paid 20 dollars for my meal in total and I also used my YELP DISCOUNT!  If I venture back to the west coast again, I'd definitely come to Eagle Cafe again.
author: Giselle V.

description: The potatoes are amazing. The plates will fill you up. Everything tastes fresh and delicious. It's a cool wharf-like atmosphere too, and clean. We walked up on a busy day and got right in, food came pretty quick.
author: Brandon C.

description:
After checking in at the Marriott on 4th Street where we were to spend a night for our Valentine Weekend Getaway, Boyfriend had the bright idea of taking a cab to the Fisherman's Wharf to hangout for couple of hours before the rain started pouring down and before our 7 PM dinner reservation.

We did the touristy thing of going into shops which I will never get tired of despite the fact that I am from the Bay Area. After watching the seals which is a must do for me everytime we go to the wharf, Boyfriend suggested we get some oysters as appetizers before our dinner at the Mission Steak Restaurant.

Oysters--a very appropriate  Valentine food as long as you don't eat too much of it otherwise you will be useless by evening time.  ;)

He took me to the Eagle Cafe where he's been to before.  So, here's the lowdown (or highlights) of the Eagle Cafe:

Date: Still Valentine's Day at 5PM

Ambiance: Touristy, lively, fun.  

Service:  Very friendly and efficient.  I barely got a chance to look at the menu but I guess it was okay since we were just there for oysters. 

Decor:  It was hard to look at anything else but the view. There was a wraparound view of the San Francisco Bay.  Each window had a million dollar view of either the Golden Gate Bridge, San Francisco Skyline, Alcatraz or the Bay.  Beautiful!!!!

Salud!:  
BF:  Banana Daquiri
Me:  Corzo Margarita

Treats:  12 Raw Oysters on Half-Shell

Overall:

1.  The view and margarita were worth going back for.
2.  I asked the server how their margarita was, She said it was very good. She was right!!
3.  The oysters were very fresh although the sizes were inconsistent. Some were actually pretty small and thin that they should have not been served but mostly good-sized.  $23 for a dozen oysters with such amazing view was actually a steal.

Total:  $54.83 including tax and tip
author: Leah E.

description: The food was AMAZING!  Their fish n chips and sourdough bread bowls were delicious.  The service was fast, even on a VERY busy Saturday lunch rush and our waitress was very friendly.  We will definitely go back here on our next trip to San Fran!
author: Kathryn T.

description:
recommendation the corned beef hash special. 
- portions are relatively big.
- everything is cooked at the appropriate level
- reminds you of home!

it was a perfect meal before intense biking around san francisco.
author: Sandra L.

description: I went here for dinner while on vacation. The place was pretty much empty, which we should have taken as a sign, but it was only 5:00 so we figured we were just there at a slow time. The staff was very friendly, the service was efficient, and there was a great view, but the food was just awful. I had the rib eye and my husband had the linguine clams, and there was simply no flavor to anything at all. Our bill totaled over $100 (we also got an appetizer and a few drinks), which was completely ridiculous for the quality of the meal we received. I would not recommend this place and I would never go back.
author: Hannah J.

description:
My experience here was traumatic.

Last Tuesday a friend and I came in for a couple of beers and a late lunch. It was a beautiful day and the view from the deck bar was amazing, so we decided to sit outside. I ordered the fried oysters and my friend ordered the fried shrimp. It went downhill from there.

When the waiter brought out our food I moved my (nearly full) beer off to the side so he could set my plate down. I failed to notice that the bar had a slight slant and the beer came sliding back down, breaking over my hand. Blood started spurting from about five different places and my lap was covered in beer. Everyone around us offered their napkins to stop the bleeding while the waiter looked on, dumbfounded. About a minute later he asked me if he could do anything, and I asked for bandaids and another beer. I really wasn't in that much pain... just grossed out from the bloody beery mess. He brought the beer and bandages and we enjoyed our (now cold) meal. 

The kicker? When he brought the bill not only did he not ask how I was, he had the audacity to charge me for both beers.

The food was good though. I'll give them that. And I'll always have the scars to remember it.
author: Caitlin N.

description: Tough service at the bar. These guys should take a happy pill. They are serving tourists. You'd think they'd want to send people home with a great experience. Apparently not!!
author: John A.

description:
Food time on the Pier!  Of course we were going to choose a place that served seafood!  

We sat inside and were seated at a little table.  Good thing we didn't order too much.  It would have been difficult to fit everything comfortably.  I agree with whoever said that the service is slow for a place that is half empty!  Also, the waitress got our order wrong.  The husband had ordered a dozen raw oysters but she only brought us 6.  In the end, we were fine with the mistake as we were already full and were only charged for 6.  

I ordered the Lobster Bisque, which I've never had before.  Well, there's a first for everything, and I'm happy to say I did enjoy this with the bread that was provided.  The husband ordered the Shrimp Po Boy Sandwich.  There was a lot of bread and not enough shrimp in my opinion.  The salad on the side was pretty good though, but we were too full to enjoy all of it.  The grapefruit juice was good, very sweet.  I'm sure there was added sugar in it, though it is supposedly freshly squeezed.  

I just checked our bill and saw that a "3% assessment is added to each check to help fund the San Francisco Health Care Initiative."  Just found out that restaurants in SF are doing this to cover the cost of health insurance for their employees.  Hmmmm.....I don't know how I feel about that. Initially outraged, but requires further consideration.
author: W W.

description: If most of your plates are over $25, I believe you should know better than to serve cocktail and tarter sauce with calamari, especially if you don't offer any other substitutes. How hard would it be to whip up a quick lemon aioli? And if the chef can't do that, my faith in the rest of his food quickly dwindles. When I said the word "aioli" to the waiter he looked at me as if I had just spoken Portuguese. (Which obviously was NOT his native language.) The problem could have simply been his obvious lack of cuisine related knowledge and not the chef's. Is it that hard to find good wait staff these days? Needless to say, I did not end up ordering here. Not even a 10% discount on SCVNGR could pin me to my chair.
author: Sommer B.

description: Really great food and view of Fisherman's Wharf. Better quality than most of the tourist restaurants in the area. Fish sandwich was wonderful! Prices not bad either and service was great!
author: Lisa Y.

description: My wife and I were in town the third week of August and were craving oysters. Made a serious error by stumbling into this tourist dive. They brought us the sorriest looking dozen oysters that we've ever laid eyes on. None were larger than a nickel and were shriveled. The guy next to us shook his head in disbelief and sent us to Hog Island down the road. Way better and with a great view.
author: V A.

description: Great place to catch a break after a long day walking around  shoping and site seeing. We had a great view outside, enjoyed some good food as well as some  great January weather.  Service was a little slow but we really didn't care as we were in no hurry. Well worth stopping for some good food and drink.
author: Joe P.

description: The service here was spectacular! From the hostess (Ashley?) to our server (Norma), both of which were new to the restaurant, everyone was so friendly. They knew how to make great suggestions and if they didn't know, they knew the right thing to say in order to find out for us! We were able to sit on the table outside overlooking Fisherman's Wharf as well. Although I was not overly impressed with the texture of the crab cake, it was fresh! My boyfriend got a chicken Caesar salad that was absolutely delicious! We will definitely be back and are anxious to try the rest of the menu items and enjoy their wonderful service!
author: Jamie Y.

description:
I was a frequent lunchtime diner at the old Eagle Cafe--which I always believed to be somewhat true to it's historical wharfside roots.

I always ordered the Salmon Eggs Benedict (very nicely done and satisfying) and my friend ordered the Crab Melt Sandwich. They also gave us a discount because we worked across the street from the pier.

Yesterday my friend was craving that very crab melt sandwich so a large group of us headed over to the pier and checked out the newly renovated Eagle Cafe. Except it wasn't the Eagle Cafe in any way but name anymore...

There was a change of owners and the renovation was not just of the building but of the entire menu.

I asked another friend to come (who had been there more recently than I) and she said "Aren't they kind of expensive?" I remembered that previously that they had been a good deal and thought she must just be being pennywise. Turns out she was right. AND no discount.

Overpriced and bad food to boot. Now it's just another Pier 39 crappy restaurant. The prices were amazingly high. The food was ridiculously bad - my fish taco was served on a cold, raw flour tortilla (yuch) and was oddly served with about 400 mediocre french fries. Weird.

My friend's previously very crabby sandwich now resembled more of a "celery with a little crab cole slaw"sandwich. Blech.

I'm only sad to write such a poor review because our server/waitress was exceptional. Accomodating to our party, attentive and very friendly and kind. SHE gets 5 stars, the owners get -1 for fucking up a perfectly fine SF institution.
author: Liza B.

description:
My Alien Wife had to renew her Green Card, another almost $400.00 out of my pocket to feed our out of control Federal Govt. You should have seen all the childish 'rules' like, no drinking your coffee.. you can keep your cup but don't drink from it.... be sure you wash your hands when after using the restroom facilities (on every wall). But I'm getting off topic. Following the 1 hour it took to process, we decided to walk a few blocks down to the Ferry Building. Jenster was hungry and it was still a bit early so we couldn't find any breakfast place. We walked up to Pier 39 and ran into several San Francisco Police Officers and asked them to point us in the direction of a good breakfast place.... Eagle Cafe was recommended with no decent.

Upon our arrival, we found it at the beginning of Pier 39, second floor with a good view of the Fisherman's Wharf. We were promptly greeted and seated by the friendly staff.... Hot Waitresses, polite and professional.

Breakfast Menu was extensive so I chose one of their Signature Omelets with Bacon, Cheese, Onions and Home Fries.... The presentation was excellent and food tasted great. Jenster enjoyed herself and more than enough food to satisfy her.... so I was safe from being 'attacked'  from my beloved spouse... who is proficient in the Three 'R' s...... 
RANTING, RAVING, RIDICULE a true test of any Male's committment.

After Breakfast, we walked the various shops. This was the weekend of the Peak of the Swine Flue or the H1 N1  whatever.... the worlds largest Cruise Ship, Mariner of the Sea, had diverted from Mexico and stopped in until Sunday along with over 3500 passengers, which had disembarked AFTER we got seated and ate. 

I approached one of the Lanky and Lovely Pier Officers and asked her "Is this the boat that does the SF Bay Cruise around Alcatraz?" She smiled and said "I dooon't think so Doofy." It's all in fun.   

Incidentally, the City/County of SF gets paid a small fortune$$$  in revenue when a ship of that size docks.

By the way... you can park for FREE... 1st hour validated at this multi-tier parking area near Pier 39. Parking for FREE in SF... unbelievable even if it is only the FIRST hour.... after that, it starts to add up fast $$$$$
author: Greg M.

description:
The Eagle Cafe serves large portions for lunch. Their burgers are good and the fries are even better. They have a raw bar and seating outside facing the bay for you to eat and watch the water lap onto the shore.

There were a few problems. 

I was a wee bit upset they were out of sourdough bread for the clam chowder bread bowls. Yes I live here but when a tourist ....

They only have ONE bathroom. Yes I said it, ONE shared bathroom for the whole entire restaurant. It is also located in the dining room, next to a couple of tables. When we were there, the restaurant was only about 10% full and I had to wait in line for the bathroom. This was due to the fact that many people from outside were coming in to use it and the hostess was not doing anything about it. This left the paying customers to wait near  the empty tables. If I was sitting at one of those tables I would not be very happy.
author: Shelly V.

description: Came here for drinks and appetizers. Their cocktails are strong but very refreshing. We ordered raw oysters to go with our drinks. They were from British columbia and they were fantastic. My only regret is to have come on a not so empty stomach. I plan on coming back soon and tasting more of their fresh cuisine.
author: Kylie L.

description: Good fish and chips but the crab salad sandwich lacked some flavor. Service was good and food came fast even on busy day.
author: Beth C.

description: Had some white fish here with skinny french fries and aoli sauce. The food was amazing and prices were better than competing restaurants at Pier 39.
author: KellyMoi M.

description: A cute little restaurant upstairs at the entrance to Pier 39. We wanted eggs benedict around lunchtime, they were still serving breakfast. I flaked and got blueberry pancakes which were amazing. He had crab cakes benedict and said they were delicious!! I tried to find out what the secret ingredient was in the country potatoes (YUM) but was told by the waiter that it was really a secret!! Definitely on our list for next time.
author: Cassondra S.

description:
The restaurant was busy but not packed and there were only two of us and a toddler.  I counted at least 5 different waiters/waitresses working.  Not one stopped to see if we had been helped and we were seated right by the door to the patio which they were bustling in and out of and must have seen us!  

Was so looking forward to trying the lobster bisque but was upset to have to walk out after being seated for 20mins+ and no one came to check on us or even put water at the table!  

The kicker was that the hostess who seated us actually thanked us on our way out the door.  Hello!!!  Somebody wasn't paying attention!  She had the opportunity to keep our business - oh well!

We marched our butts down to the Fog Harbor Fish House....YUM!!!  They saved the day...or our stomachs rather...see that review!
author: Sara S.

description: We had a couple of beers and sandwiches here.  We had to wait at least 25 minutes for a table,and when we finally were seated and looked around there were at least 8 other empty tables.  What the!?!?!  While the beer was cold and the sandwiches were...eh, OK, I don't think I'd go back.  I waited a long time for the waitress to bring some ketchup-geez you would think any time fries are served they would bring ketchup with it, wouldn't you?  Price was way too high for a mediocre meal!
author: Karen S.

description:
In full disclosure, I wouldn't eat here.  For that matter, I wouldn't eat anywhere in Fisherman's Wharf on a BET except Starbucks and maybe the sourdough place, Bourdain or whatever it is.  And, OK, fine, Rainforest Cafe because it keeps the bobbleheads quiet for an hour if you can time it so you can skip the store.

What I WILL do here, again and again, I hope, is drink beers and shots in an atmosphere than can only be called "faux naval military alcoholic" with as many as 12 people at any given time who truly believe that rehab is for quitters, while looking out at the bay and the people (that word is used in finger quotes for maximum annoyance) who still think that the Hard Rock Cafe is a pretty cool idea.

Alcoholism and superiority are hard to find in the same bar.  4 stars.
author: John H.

description:
I brought my family here for lunch while visiting Fisherman's Wharf and was disappointed, really disappointed.  I had been here before, years ago, and remembered it being fantastic - I ordered the open-faced crab melt then and ordered the open faced crab melt this time too... Before the sandwich was not pretentious and delicious. This time the sandwich was super pretentious and so salty that I sent it  back to the kitchen.  I don't know what is going on in their kitchen, but I ordered a side salad to replace my spoiled entree and even the salad was overly salted! Who salts a salad?!?!  Anyway, none of us were impressed by the food, though the portions were good for the cost. But, our waiter was not at all attentive - I had to ask THREE times for my Shirley Temple (yes, I drink Shirley Temples).  

I would have given this place 2 stars, but because it holds a sentimental place in my heart I threw an extra star up there.
author: Maryam S.

description: I went 3 stars because the food was pretty good. It did, however, take a long time to get our food...about 45 minutes. They said the rice was not done and had to make more. They came over to the table 3 times to apologize and gave us 20% off the bill. I had the fish and chips (it was not bad) and my wife had crab stuffed prawns over rice with an amazing sauce. Food was good and overall service was also good. Will eat there again.
author: P B.

description: Five adults and four kids on black friday, only a couple minutes wait. Nice friendly staff kept drinks full. Food was descent and seafood was fresh. Kids meals are big enough to split. Check in on yelp and get 10% off check, which helped a lot.
author: daniel S.

description: our 1st stop in town, after checking into hotel.  Normal cafe food, with a great view and right on pier 39.
author: Jeff J.

description: My dad took me and my brother here ever sunday until we were about 12.  If you find yourself downtown after a long night and want a REAL breakfast where you are not worry about calories or some fancy presentation carved into your pancakes, this is definitely the place.  Pier 39 yes, but this place had been here for years and has never changed (except when they had to move it to the second floor some years back)  If you feel like feeding the sea lions, you can catch them sunning themselves out the back.  Try to ignore the fact that they look just like you feel after that long night at the bar.
author: Mike V.

description: We had breakfast and the food was excellent. The only thing I wouldn't  suggest is the French toast which was mushy. The place is small but we sat out on the patio overlooking the pier. Dont come if you are in a hurry as the service is a bit slow. I didn't appreciate the hostess cramming in another family next us but all in all it was worth it all. The breakfast was the best we had in the srea
author: Carol F.

description: I've upgraded my review to 2 stars after being contacted by the owner.  She invited us to return for a pampered experience.  Although our return is not likely since we are not local, I think that there is something to be said for good customer service which seems to be greatly suffering in our society.
author: Trish G.

description: The food was good and was well prepared. Service was absolutely terrible. We waited about 45 minutes for our food. Gabriel was our waiter and was rude. After asking for a water refill twice, we were still not served. We all left with empty drink glasses having had zero refills. We did not see our waiter again after he brought our drinks. We had to ask another employee for our bill.
author: Josh F.

description: I always say the measure of a good establishment correlates directly with how they handle adverse situations. When our dungenese crab Benedict arrived at our table we found a long nasty hair stuck in the crab. They apologized and quickly brought us a new one. I have to say, it was fantastic. For $22 I thought I might not see the value but I did. It was huge and came loaded with crab and a large serving of potatoes. Good enough to share. Unfortunately they did not handle the hair situation properly. They did not discount or offer a dessert or anything. That's a big no-no in my book. You screw up, you make it up.  Plus the waitress kept rushing me and was kind of rude.
author: adrian s.

description: Went here during America's Cup and sat outside.  They were great with my friend's little dog.  Drinks were very good.  Service was attentive.  Food was very good too.  The views from the outside are wonderful.  I'll definitely go back.
author: Donna W.

description: Went in for breakfast based on a recommendation from a friend back home in Virginia. Beautiful surroundings, clean and cheery atmosphere. Pleasant wait staff (and they were moving fast, but attentive). I had the corned beef hash, eggs with a fresh roll and coffee. It was really good. You would not be disappointed visiting this restaurant.
author: Kevin K.

description: Had the lobster bisque bread bowl and sat outside to enjoy the view of the bay.  The bisque was very well flavored, with plenty of lobster.  I give this place a solid four star rating!!  Next time I am back in San Fran, I will look forward to returning to this place.
author: Erik B.

description: Normally I wouldn't be caught dead eating dinner at Pier 39 but having just left a trendy eatery down the street that wouldn't serve us a hamburger off the lunch menu (see my Butterfly review) we decided to forge this unknown territory and have seat. Of course we ordered hamburgers and were informed they were on the lunch menu but our excellent server Waymond, brought us the lunch menus to make our selection. What a refreshing change from our earlier encounter at Butterfly. We were served huge burgers, probably typical overpriced Pier 39 fare, but with friendly attitudes and quick service. Thumbs up to Waymond and Eagle Cafe!
author: Suzy S.

description:
I'm surprised to see that this place has such low ratings, when my friend and I went this past Sunday we thought it was great! Maybe it was because the Blue Angels were in town, and in honor of Fleet Week they decided to make the food extra delicious, but we were both enthralled with our food!

My friend ordered the veggie omelette with egg whites only, and it was light and the veggies tasted fresh! The eggs were scrambled and cooked to just the right degree of fluffiness. The potatoes and onions were so good, crispy and hearty.

My dish had me swooning. I ordered the peanut butter and banana stuffed french toast. Why have I never seen this at other restaurants and how could I have missed out on something so good! Soft gooey French toast lathered with peanut butter, grilled with bananas, and covered in freshly sliced bananas - I even added a tiny bit of strawberry jam to see what it tasted like - so good!!!

Must..eat..more!
author: Katherine P.

description: The food was awesome.  I enjoyed the jumbo shrimp and my friend loved the clam chowder. They have awesome views and the staff is very friendly.  What more could you ask for.
author: Sharisse W.

description: The restaurant does not have the prime real estate at the fishermen's wharf pier 39. They did not have the views but the reason I am a fan and a 4 stars was really because of the friendly service and really good food. Their food presentation was two thumbs up. One couple next to us ordered the seafood platter and wow, it looked great. We had the oysters on the shell and it was good. I order the tilapia which tasted fresh not overwhelming with salt. Our waiter was very sweet. Just great service. The manager stopped by our table to say hello. I really liked this place. I hope for a next time at this place.
author: J C.

description: OMG! Worst restaurant ever! Had to return utensils because they still had food caked on it. Then sent back a glass that also had food & grease left along the rim. Ordered the linguini with clam sauce but sent that back to the kitchen too because it was way too salty & peppery to be palatable. I wasn't the only one on the table to comment on the saltiness of the food  I've never sent food back to the kitchen before. This was a first for me. Service was horrible as well. I asked for a refill of hot water but the waiter ran out of water in his carafe before he filled my cup half way. He apologized but then NEVER came back to finish pouring the rest!  We had to request for water refills from wait staff that continually bypassed our table. The sourdough bread was brought to the table stone cold in the middle like they just yanked it out of the fridge. Then to top off an already horrible experience, they charged me for the linguini I sent back to the kitchen!  Even the manager of the place was apathetic. The restaurant's only saving grace was their one waitress. She was very kind and friendly. She helped to fix our bill and apologized. I would NOT recommend this place unless you like dirty silverware and food so salty you'd swear it had a whole salt lick melted into it.
author: Jodi L.

description: This is my favorite place for corned beef hash in San Francisco so far!  Great breakfast...the service can be hit-or miss though.
author: J P.

description: It was ok. I think there are probably much better places near by. Crab cakes were nasty. Chowder was so so.  Keep ok walking good seafood can't be far away.
author: Ken N.

description:
So me and my girlfriend were looking around at all the food places in that area. The first place we did notice was the eagle cafe on the top level because we walked from that connected walk way to the parking structure. So after looking around, we just decided lets try to eagle cafe. Plus i heard some guy raving about it when we were staring at the menus about how its all remodeled and what not. So we get seated look at the menu and notice prices are a little steep, my girlfriend got the baked oyster with the Manhattan style or whatever, 4 for 12 bucks. So you expect to get oyster with meat right? NO, u get a bunch of this weird spinach cream sauce while digging in that crap for an oyster u pull on something that probably was canned oysters. TERRIBLE. Her ceaser salad was about 10 or 12 bucks for a CEASER SALAD? it lacked in taste, was kind of water too. So was my clam chowder in a bowl, pretty runny not thick and creamy, kept biting into the taste of sand from the oysters, pretty bad tasting. should of just got to one of those vendors on the street and got a bowl there. Oh i forgot to mention that these three items took over 20+ mins for our order to come out! arent these considered appetizer type foods on the menu? while people who were seated later than us go their damn meals. You have to be kidding with this place? OVERPRICED SLOW SERVICE, while every waiter or waitress there was raving about how good each food on the menu was, such BS! Never will i go back to this place.

I would of been more satisfied with a some french fries and a corndog. How sad is that?
author: David K.

description: First time here at this restaurant in the pier and by the water. Busy place Host was friendly it didn't take a long time for us to be seated. Place was cozy. Coffee was unlimited and orange juice was fresh smooth. I had Strawberry French Toast the portion was big, food was delicious. My girlfriend had toast, bacon was crunchy cook right, fruits. They made sure you left their full and not hungry. Would recommend here to try if you want a place to go for breakfast and will come back. Price was good.
author: Gruber T.

description: The food was amazing and the portions were a good size. The service was great. The restaurant is a bit small, but the view makes up for it. Only down size is that I found a hair in my food. However, they were very apologetic and did what they could to make it a great experience. The location was great.
author: Gloria H.

description:
It's tough for a girl staying on the wharf that doesn't like seafood.  

After our Alcatraz tour (highly recommended) we had lunch at the Eagle Cafe.  We were tired, sunburnt and hungry.  The burger and fries hit the spot (the beer wasn't too bad either).  

I would have no qualms eating here again, if stuck on the wharf.
author: Lisa M.

description:
The way i see it, if every tourist judged the city by this restaurant, the city would be a very quiet place.

Upon entering we were greeted by the bartender who invited us to sit anywhere. My friend and i were in the mood to try some oysters. Upon seeing the menu prices we realized that it was all we would be able to afford for the rest of the evening. Although the bartender was attentive to us (we chose to sit at the bar to watch espn) i have to say the prices were quite intimidating. We ordered the platter with 24 oysters and they ranged from the size of your palm to the size of a penny (no joke). Design was pretty, taste unfortunately did no match its looks.

There was a woman in the kitchen who didn't seem too happy to be there, if anything she seemed somewhat angry/unhappy. I believe in coming into a warm and welcoming restaurant. Don't go in here without expecting to leave with a empty stomach and wallet.
author: Dan N.

description: In a hurry, looking for something fast and good. I had the grilled shrimp and she had the fried oysters. They both were both very good. The couple next to us had the raw oysters and seemed happy. Bar tender Gary (I think) was very friendly, and had a good sense of humor. Drinks were a little on the weak side though. We will return next time we are in town.
author: Ray H.

description:
More like 2.5 *
Fairly good food; crab cakes etc. but it was expensive...and at Fisherman's Wharf
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Great view, great bloody marys, and a very nicely done brunch plate.
author: Keds S.

description: Great fish and chips and fresh oysters.It was really good but the place is a little small. We were seated next to the bathroom but the food made up for that. There was even entertainment....lol!!! Someone was trapped in the bathroom for about 20mins it was hilarious. They used spoons. forks, knives and a credit card to try and free this guy. Finally they just took the lock off and he was out. Besides that food and service was great!!! You also get 10% off your bill if you checkin on Yelp so that was a plus
author: Amara B.

description:
I ordered the fish and chips. San Francisco's #1 Fish & Chips or something. I'm gullible like that.

I expected the fish to resemble chicken McNuggets. The crunchy kind of batter. I don't know how fish & chips are supposed to be, but I like them my way. So when they brought out the plate, I was taken by surprise. The portions are great (had lunch and dinner with one lunch entree). But as I said, I was looking forward to the heavy batter, not the light batter. The fries were seasoned. Complimented the light batter well. It felt like fancy fish & chips instead of casual finger food. 

$19 for fish and chips only. I don't think I'll come back to Fisherman's Wharf for this. I don't think I'll go back to the Wharf for anything really.
author: Justin L.

description:
I went on a Monday morning so maybe my experience was a little different than someone who might have come for dinner or lunch on a weekend. When I walked in it was nearly empty, the staff was all smiling and the few people that were seated seemed to be enjoying themselves.

My father in law paid so I wasn't hurt by the price but I did feel a little guilty ordering the Crab Cake Benedict for $16.95. But I honestly would have paid for it myself it was so good. It was huge so I literally ate a quarter of my plate and took the rest to go. But it was a near perfect meal. 

The English muffin sat on top of spinach with a slice of tomato, a crab cake, poached egg and hollandaise on top. Yummy. Plus these amazing potatoes with bell pepper and onion. Oh and a slice of cantaloupe.  

My husband got the polish sausage scramble and that too was delightful. I'd say this should be saved for a special brunchy type occasion, but just for kicks, but i think it was damn well worth the money (that I didn't spend)
author: Jenna R.

description: I hate to say this, but the chowder in a bread bowl is good stuff. The hot soup warms you instantly on a cold day. The carbs from the bread keep the warmth going for awhile after. The whole 10+ years living in SF, I don't think I once had clam chowder in a bread bowl. Now I am a tourist I guess.
author: Scott M.

description:
Yes, you'll probably find more tourists here than locals but the waiters are all locals, does that count? I was surprised by the number of Asian male wait staff. One was kinda cute (by my "if I were still in college standards"). The place has been an Italian family business since 1929. They literally lifted the whole restaurant and moved and placed it on the 2nd floor when Pier 39 was built and refurbished the exterior to match the Pier 39 design. It blends so well that it looks like the building has always been a part of Pier 39. Above the bar is a displayed collection of Navy caps including a SFPD one. Naval pics decorate the walls and it's a cozy restaurant with partial pier view. 

Our wait staff was very no nonsense efficient. Prices for breakfast are not worse than at any other SF restaurant & hubby thought it was more reasonable than some place like Perry's near the Embarcadero. Coffee $2.95, Sm OJ $3.00. His classic eggs Benedict $9.95 came with 2 muffins topped with eggs and Canadian bacon and lots of spicy, paprika flavored chunks of soft potatoes. Cutely garnished with a sprig of rosemary in a slice of cantaloupe and slice of orange. My "homemade" corned beef hash was too mushy, and was a disappointing small portion. My potato (same as hubby's) portions was 3x the size of my hash. Where's the beef? I asked for poached eggs which came in a separate ramekin. Get this, they ask how you want the eggs poached - soft, med or hard! And it was done right. 2 wonderful slices of buttered wheat bread, the good stuff with oats baked on the crust, not the commercial Wonder bread kind. 
The tourist at the other table was enjoying his bloody Mary special of the day. Nothing like booze at 10AM to start the day, right? There's a SF Health surcharge and hubby was happy to see it's one of the few places who puts a pre-calculated scale at the bottom of the receipt to tell you how much tip to give at 15%, 18%, 20%. Unlike at most places who calculate the tip based on including the tax (why would you tip on the tax?), they calculate the tip based solely on the cost of the food. Not bad food for a touristy area.
author: Ry T.

description:
I haven't been to Pier 39 in over a decade as I try to avoid the tourist traps, but found myself in the neighborhood after the Re-opening Celebration of the Angel Island Immigration Station. 

Seating at the restaurant was pretty quick, especially since we were a party of 8.  They sat us at 2 tables next to each other, which was fine.  The view was lovely, even on a cold, rainy SF day.  We had the fried calamari, steamed clams, fish and chips, clam chowder and a crab salad sandwich.  The clam chowder was bland, but after adding in the juice from the steamed clams was much better.  (I shouldn't have to add in additional clam juice to their clam chowder, but it was the only thing that was going to help it.)

Calamari was tasty, but a little heavily battered.  Crab sandwich was disappointing.  The bread was too thick and the crab salad didn't have much crab flavor.  Fish and chips were good and the salad that accompanied my sandwich was very nicely dressed in a tarragon/balsamic vinegar dressing.  Steamed clams were very good and the best of the dishes.  I had a lemon drop from the bar and it was also delicious.

So, in summary, I would come here for drinks and appetizers to soak in the view, but this wouldn't be a destination restaurant for me.  The food was average, but the waitstaff was very nice and attentive.
author: ChaChaCha ..

description: I LOVE LOVE ABSOLUTELY LOVE their food. I haven't had one bad experience here. I try going every few months, but the trek to SF gets longer and longer. I bring out of town guests to the Pier and this is where I get my grub on. They have a full bar, what's not to love about alcohol at lunch? The wait staff has always been very friendly and they're spot on with their recommendations. Only complaint is you have to pay to park. But it's located at a tourist trap so I guess I can't really complain.
author: Jade H.

description: Go here if were kidnapped and not allowed to eat for days. That's how much food you'll get on your plate. A mountain's worth. Though, while a lot of food, it's so good, it can't be beat. The Po'Boy sandwich is definitely worth having, among many other items. It's pricey, but it's at Pier 39. If you took the time to get there, and get the experience, enjoy yourself and the food, and ignore the prices.
author: David L.

description: We got to Fisherman's Wharf on Labor Day weekend so it was an absolute zoo. We saw the Eagle Cafe and noticed they had oysters on the half shell and that's what we wanted (plus a meal) so we decided to eat there. The oysters tasted so fresh it was as if they were just caught - and maybe they were, I don't know. So, yes, very good oysters, we could have had a lot more than the half dozen we shared but we had to save room for our main course. For that, we had the Alaskan Cod sandwich w/ fries. The fries were fresh cut potatoes into shoestrings - my personal favorite way to prepare french fries and the sandwich was excellent too. The sandwich was a generous portion so we definitely go our $$$'s worth. The sandwich could have had a little more of the sauce on it but other than that an excellent meal.
author: Marc W.

description:
I moved to San Francisco from the Midwest having never been here before, and partially because of that we ended up moving into a place just a few blocks from Fisherman's Wharf. Despite the general touristy vibe Pier 39 gives off, there are good things - but the trick is to go early and off-season. 

One of our pleasant surprises were the breakfasts at the Eagle Cafe. I have never, ever eaten there later than 11 a.m., because by Noon the Wharf is chocked full of ass-bellied mouths-agape tourists, with families of crying toddlers, shuffling elderlies and people looking for the perfect "Only In San Francisco!" fleece pullover. 

We are just a short walk from Mama's, but sometimes I don't feel like standing in line for an overrated meal accentuated by angry looks from others if I so much as dawdle briefly to examine a newspaper after I finish my meal. And so, we have enjoyed several morning trips to Eagle Cafe, and every time we've enjoyed it. 

The eggs benedict are solid, the regular bacon/sausage/whatevs-and-eggs are good and if you're really, really hungry, give the ham steak a try - but be prepared to feel the need to go right back to bed. 

If you're an omelette and meat fan, try their chef's special - another treat that should only be eaten once in a rare while, because otherwise your arteries will commit sepeku. 

The only reason I didn't go for 4 out of 5 was drink prices. If you're somebody who enjoys the occasional breakfast cocktail - and I am - you'll find their prices a bit too much. A Bloody Mary or Irish Coffee cost almost as much as their enormous breakfasts. If you're looking for a real eye-opener with your toast and eggs, you'll drop far more than you initially intended for breakfast. 

Also, they won't give out the password for the WiFi signal. Or our waitress during our last visit just had no idea what it was and gave us a lame excuse.
author: Drew H.

description: Horrible... 3 out of 4 meals my table ordered came out wrong.  I ordered a bacon cheeseburger... I got blue cheese on a burger... Sent it back, came back 2 minutes later after they scrapped off the blue cheese and tossed on American and bacon... The bun still had the wrong cheese on it.  I won't get started on the rest of the meals.
author: Ian R.

description: My family was visiting from Hawaii and I took them here.  This ended up being a huge mistake.  The oysters were so small but that was not the worst part.  The servers were acting as if we were invisible and when we waive our hand to ask for service, we got no response.  Nice location, horrible service.  Don't even think about using the restroom here, it takes forever.  Won't be going there again.
author: Sandra R.

description: Nice, airy and clean.  Food portions were huge and a full bar.  Nice view of Pier 39.  Had the veggie omelete and it was very tasty.  Mimosas were good too.
author: Debbie V.

description: I went here for breakfast and it was amazing, of course a little pricey. I had the  crab cakes about $22 but was a large serving of crab and was really good. I am disappointed that I have never gone to this restaurant before, I've always just walked past it. Very pleased with the food:)
author: Nicole T.

description: Very nice experience here. The best place to eat with a view of people, sailboats, etc. If it's too cold, eat inside, where you'll feel like you're dining in seafood royalty. You have to try to Fisherman's platter, it'll be enough to for two. Parking validated, good times...
author: Dominic S.

description:
This place is great!  It's upstairs on Pier 39.  The view of the bay is great and their food is even better!  Service is great.  

MUST TRY:

~Garlic Butter Clams (it's on the appetizer list)
~Garlic Bread
~Oysters on a half shell
~Grilled Salmon Salads

Just a fair warning, their portions are HUGE, when I said HUGE I mean Ginormously so.  I ordered their Club Sandwich and was enough to feed 4 people at my table.  Their Garlic Fries are great. 

Be careful about Drinks, they don't give you free refills so when you get the bill don't be mad at the waitress.  Food is Great and Service is very friendly.  

I have no complaints except that they only have 1 restroom.  But hey the view and food is great!
author: Kym H.

description: They were able to seat a large party on a Saturday evening and they have a nice view--that was good.  That's where it stops.  OK service, lousy food.  The real problem was that two people in our party got sick later that night--a real bad headache and stomachache.  The only things they had in common were that they had a beer and some oysters.  I would recommend Fog Harbor next to it--we went there the next night and had good food, good service, same view.
author: J V.

description: Yeah, I know this is a place for tourists, and believe me, I normally wouldn't have come here, except that my brother and his wife were visiting and we had to do the obligated stop at Pier 39/Fisherman's Wharf (along with the Golden Gate, etc.)  We sat at the bar to have drinks while waiting out the downpour.  They make a mean spicy bloody mary (one of the best I've had), have a good selection of beers, and have delicious fresh oysters on the half-shell.  The prices are a bit high, but given the location, that's not surprising.  Service was solid, and they validate parking for the structure across the street.  The interior of the restaurant is really lovely--bright, spacious, and classy (for a lack of a better descriptor).
author: Beth K.

description:
great breakfast place!

big portions, great service.  the french toast is good, so is the crab omelette!
author: Liezl S.

description: This place was packed at 2:30 for lunch...but I think it was with other desperately hungry tourists, like me.  We sat at the bar.  The food was okay, but nothing to write home about.  With so many great restaurants around, I would not go back to this one. Except, maybe, for happy hour.
author: Holly S.

description: Been here a few times, the food is very good and the staff a great as well. The only downside is that it gets very busy on the weekends. The atmosphere is great as well very nice inside, and nice views of the ocean if you choose to sit outside.
author: Chris S.

description: There burgers are huge!! and oysters are delicious!!!  They have a full bar and a huge selection of seafood and american food.  Portions are really big but you pay for what you get.
author: Drew F.

description: Great food and service! I love eating my breakfast sitting over the water! I ate there evry morning out on the deck! Great prices too!
author: Kirsten F.

description:
I heard that there was such a fuss to preserve this cafe. Pro'ally all those longshoremen crying about where they were gonna get their whiskies to cry over the misery of seeing their jobs taken over by the metal cranes made in China that hauled those containers off freighters. Sooo Warren Simmons had to make a concession to that all once powerful union in the 70s to conceed that some need a stiffy to keep up the vascular pumping before cardioinfarction sets in to carotid arteries.  Just get a drink and then skeedadle your way out to revisit other tourist traps for out of towners that insist they want to get that kitsch musical cable car made in "you-know-where...the big C_ _ N_" no that ends in an "A" not any other letter...pity the fool that decides to eat here!

You can always go to sooo many other places in this amazing city for great seafood, or whatever catches your fancy.
author: miriam b.

description: We had a party of five for lunch.  Hostesses (2 of them) looked and acted like they hated their jobs, told us 10 minutes and it was over 30. Food was absolutely terrible. The crab salad sandwiches (3 in our party had those) were watery and tasteless. Cheap canned crab (and not much of it) on a wilted piece of old lettuce open face on a stale bun with cold french fries. One person in our party had the fish and chips, fish good but with cold fries. The crab salad sandwiches came out first then 5 minutes later the fish and chips and the last person's meager looking sandwich. Service was so-so. Waiter efficient but never check to see if everything was OK or if we needed something else. We would not go back again. Very disappointed, we were hosting out of town guest.
author: Casey S.

description: The service here was family friendly. We have a two year old which some restaurants, even on the wharf, will gawk at. Eagle didn't and made us feel welcome. The crab app was decent and I like the way they serve their horseradish. The chowder was also good, but a bit heavy on the cream. Thus, I recommend that you only get a cup. We ordered the kiddy burger, but they actually serve an adult sized burger minus the fixings which I found to be a waste of food. But luckily I only ordered a bowl of chowder so I helped my daughter eat the rest of her burger.
author: Url R.

description: Great service, staff was very friendly, nice views and the food was very good!
author: Jason T.

description:
Nothing like the old Eagle, if you remember it. Rich food, large portions, good bar. One of the better Pier 39 eateries.

You'll like it if:
 You hanker for a King's Breakfast.
author: Jabe N.

description:
I was down at Pier 39 hanging out with some friends, and was looking for a place to have some lunch, and the Eagle Cafe was right in the beginning of the long line of shops and restaurants, so we decided to give it a try.  

    We walked in and were greeted right away.  It seemed like a very clean place and had a nice view as well.  We got our table and most of my friends had seafood, but I opted for the club sandwich.  
  
    We got our food pretty fast, and I couldn't believe how huge my club sandwich was!   I could barely get my mouth around it, and it was delicious!   It had tons of ham and bacon, and I could barely finish it.  The fries were really good too, not those greasy fast food fries.  

   My friends loved their seafood and I loved my sandwich!   We will definitely be back.  I will have to try some dessert next time, since they all looked so good, but was too full this time after that monster sandwich.  I would definitely recommend this place to anyone who loves food, and has a big appetite!
author: keith i.

description:
I absolutely love this place.  The food was not only yummy, but the price is reasonable for the location, quality of food, service, ambiance, & portion size.  My husband and I ordered two different dishes and two appetizers, but if we knew how big the portion was going to be, we would have cut an appetizer or shared one of the dishes.  

The restaurant was very busy, but they were still able to seat us and get our food pretty quickly.   Overall, exceptional place - I definitely recommend!
author: Ngoc P.

description: We were visiting fisherman's wharf, and the menu looked good. THe food was pretty good- the crab salad sandwich was great. The drinks/margaritas were okay-next time i'd just get beer. The service was a bit slow.
author: Sarah W.

description:
This place is wonderful!  I can't say enough about this place.  I try to go there every time I am in the city.  The food is delicious and the servers are fast and efficient.  I especially love their crab melt and clam chowder.  The portions are so big that you can share it with someone and still have leftovers.

Their prices are a little pricey but each dish can serve about 2 so it sort of balances out.  The view is also spectacular.  You can  get a view of Colt Tower, Alcatraz and the seals if you decide to seat outside.  Overall this place has everything you could want.
author: Mui D.

description: wasn't impressed with the food especially for as much as it cost. Service was severely  lacking, part of our order was lost so part of our party didn't even get there food until after half of us had already finished eating, and they didn't even apologize about their  mistake. Lastly i don't see why they put's two tables so close to the restrooms, we spent the whole meal with a line or people standing next to us to use the single restroom.
author: Jacob P.

description:
June 23, 2009



Dear Manager, Eagle Cafe

My family and I visited your restaurant for lunch and we ordered clam chowder,
fish and chips, cheeseburger, and grilled cheese. The clam chowder was 1/2 filled in the bread bowl.  My fish and chips were chewy, overcooked and dry.  The fish and chips were $18.00.  I am asking for a refund of the only the fish and chips, they were unacceptable.  I called to let the staff know and all they said was thanks for calling.  I feel these days, we try to choose wisely where we spend our money and we chose your restaurant.  We were very disappointed. All we are asking for is a refund of the fish.  Please, call us so we can come to some arrangement.  Then I can say how helpful you were on yelp.
author: Lena T.

description:
I work at a hotel in downtown San Francisco, and one of my guests came back from eating breakfast at the Eagle Cafe and raved about it. When I later had family visiting from out of town, I decided to take them there to check it out. 

It's conveniently located at the front of the pier and had awesome views of both bridges from inside. The hostess who sat us was very polite and quick to greet us and seat us at a nice table by the window. I was pleased to find that there was an abundance of crab on the menu (one of my favorites, plus a treat for someone not from the bay area). I had to try their "crabby mary", which is a sort of bloody mary with crab in it, served with crackers. It was amazing! My family members ordered the corned beef hash, and a crab omelette, which the 3 of us shared as the portions are pretty large. 

Overall, I was impressed with this place - the location on the pier, the food, and mostly the customer service was great - I was always able to get my waiter's attention if they hadn't already come by to check on us, and we didn't wait long at all for our food. I was pleasantly surprised, and will go back again!
author: Louisa J.

description: Eagle Cafe is a great place to take the family. Our kids really enjoy the fish & fries. Since the portions are nice, they also like to pick on our plates to try new things. The fried calamari is a must every time we eat there. The view is really nice if your sitting outside on the balcony. You could see the sea lions without smelling them. The food is very good, service is always warm and welcoming. Definitely one of our stops in the city when we go.
author: Nannette H.

description:
My first review, last weekend had some cousins visting from out of town. They wanted go to the wharf and we end up eating at the eagle, cause that was the first resturant from the garage skywalk.
Cousins wanted fresh oysters and we walkin, oyster was very fresh and food were very good too. Didnt expect a tourist area to have such good food, Will have to take the family down next time.
author: G P.

description: Cute little place.  Wasn't really busy when I went, but I ate around 5:30pm so I could've been early on the rush.  My fried shrimp was not too bad, but my wine was excellent and since it wasn't busy, they were at least very attentive.  The prices are a little overpriced.  Avoid the cupcakes, I think mine was sitting all day so the frosting was hard and gross.
author: Olivia M.

description: I liked  Eagle Cafe because it seemed to be one of the only sit-down places we could find to get breakfast by the pier. The food was pretty good although a little on the pricey side for breakfast stuff. Portions were large and were served on plates you would normally put a Thanksgiving turkey on (didn't like that so much). There was no wait and the dining area was open and airy with lots of windows. Not the best breakfast I have ever had but certainly not the worst.
author: Sarah F.

description: This place is hilarious, with the white table clothes, flat screens showing sports, full bar and the most ridiculous portions and plate sizes at a price. I imagine the kitchen garbage here weighs tons and looks like a Vegas hotel restaurant dumpster with all the leftovers. The Cobb salad is piled high with meat that you can't finish because you pretty much get sick of chewing or you just run out of time. The sandwiches and fish tacos with half a fry basket of fries are tasty enough. Breakfast is pretty standard and wins if you want to take a nap afterward. There is a full bar with good Bloody Marys and I have seen friends happy with some good quality scotch. Expensive because of the tourists, location and amounts of plated food. I wish they had a locals menu with smaller portions and prices. Nice views and a friendly enough staff. Not bad for Pier 39.
author: William R.

description: If your near the top 10 tourist trap that is pier 39 check out Eagle Cafe. What's really cool is that it was moved here from it's original location back when pier 39 was first opened. I mean the whole entire building was moved here!!! It's at the very entrance of pier 39 on the second level. An original 1928 San Francisco cafe. Up until recently it was operated as the original Eagle Cafe but now owned and operated by a new company with multiple locations they kept the original name on the building. I haven't been here since that change.
author: Rob W.

description: Semi-ok food, lousy service. Wait-staff was socializing and goofing off most of the time. Our food came out very slowly and 1 of the items we ordered never arrived, although they then tried to charge us for it. I don't feel the need to eat there again.
author: Jennifer F.

description: Eagle Cafe is the best place to go for seafood. The raw bar is so awesome and fresh! I love the oysters and the many varieties that they have. I usually go for the raw stuff but the Oyster Rockefeller is a must try, that oyster baked on a half shell with the pesto sauce it' so great together. My favorite breakfast item is the Crab and Salmon Benedict. They have very good size portion and great quality food.  You don't get that at most resturant.  It's either small portions with great quality or big portions with bad quality.  At the Eagle you get it all!  Every time I am in San Francisco I have to stop by the Eagle.  Very friendly people and great food, what more can you ask for! One more thing Get the Bloody Mary there, best I ever had anywhere!
author: Thai L.

description: I come across the bay on the ferry and love to stop in and have lunch. My husband and I have been totally satisfied the 4 or 5 times we have been to the Eagle Cafe. Love the location and on a nice day when the Blue Angels are flying in Oct  for Fleet Week it is so fun... come early to get a good seat...Most importantly the food is great. Never have been disappointed... fish & chips, clam chowder, oysters are great! We took our granchildren on our anniversary and they too enjoyed. Service also at the top of the list. Try Eagle Cafe, you will not be disapoointed.... not the average tourist restaurant by a long shot.
author: Marilyn R.

description: I love the salmon eggs benedict they make here and make a point to stop by when I'm in town for breakfast. The portions are huge!
author: L B.

description:
If you read nothing else of my review, read this: You MUST try the OYSTERS ROCKEFELLER!!!!!

Yes, since I live in SF I was one of those people who would say, "I'm not eating at Pier 39! It's for tourists!" But now I can no longer say that.... I had the chance to eat at Eagle Cafe over the weekend. I will say that I only gave the place 4 stars merely because I only had drinks and appetizers while I was there, so I feel like I can't give 5 stars since I didn't have the "full experience". But for what I tried, it was great! The service was great, the drinks were great, the ocean/marina view was nice, and the highlight of it all....was the oysters!! Not only were the raw oysters wonderful, but the Oysters Rockefeller were divine!! (If you don't know, Rockefeller style is baked oysters with cheese and spinach, and if you like, eaten on a cracker!) If you like oysters, you must try the Oysters Rockefeller at Eagle Cafe at least once in your life!
author: Kate M.

description: Just had breakfast there this morning due to the positive reviews. The breakfast is excellent. Although, it was a little different having a hamburger bun as toast. The potatoes are fantastic and my wife and daughter said the blueberry pancakes were very good. I highly recommend this place.
author: Gene I.

description: Hangar Steak was best value on the menu. Very good service and great location on Pier 39
author: Fabio R.

description: In fairness, this review is for the Bloody Mary's that we had to begin our City weekend.  They were awesome!  The bartender mixed everything in the glass and even grated fresh horseradish for the Mary's. I loved the garnishes that they had on a skewer-olive, onion, pickled carrot, jalapeno, and lemons.  I asked for extra spicy and boy did the bartender deliver!  It was so good and the service was excellent!
author: Grace C.

description:
Confession time: I've never eaten here. My friend and I went on a bender adventure together a few weekends ago and we happened to be in Pier 39's neck of the wood. Always up for playing tourist after a few cocktails we decided to say "eh, what the heck" and marched up the stairs into Eagle Cafe (much different than say the Eagle Tavern but I'll save that for another review-ha ha wink wink). 
The first impression I got was wow, honey we are in touristville. But never fret! We met Jennifer (sp?) who is BY FAR, one of, if not THE coolest bartenders in the Fisherman's Wharf/Pier 39 area! First off all she is one boisterous person who's energy is infectious! Secondly, for all us locals she's an Italian girl born and raised in North Beach so as my friend and I were informing a young man from New Jersey in town for the day, where a decent jazz club or two (or more like 5) was she decided to clue NJ boy as to where the best place in all SF was to get foccacia for the plane ride home (she told him that sourdough bread is to be shared at home, foccacia from North Beach is to be kept a secret between you and the plane). Love her! She made my friend and I some of the best oyster shooters I've had in awhile (mmm....oyster shooters) with fresh (and I mean scraped from the root fresh) horseradish. My buddy, a proclaimed oyster hater (think Grouchy smurf), loved it so much he needed a second (which was fine by me because I love oysters and he was buying). Seriously San Francisco, go there just once to meet this young lady and have a meal and an oyster shooter (or 2). If you happen to come across her, you will not be disappointed.
author: Veronica G.

description: I used to go to the Eagle Cafe for lunch sometimes as it is one of the more low-key places to eat on Pier 39 due to the 2nd floor location. I would always order the Patty Melt. It like how simple it looks with the grilled white bread with beef patty inside, melted cheese and grilled onion flowing all over. It is greasy but very good.
author: Richard W.

description: Good food. A little bit pricey, but what do you expect in Fisherman's Wharf? It is the tourist part of the city on the bay so naturally the prices are a little bit inflated. The calamari was worth it on the appetizer.
author: E S.

description: The people and atmosphere here are very friendly and not pretentious like some of the nearby businesses.  We were seated immediately.  My glass of water never went empty the entire time I was there.  I tried their crab cocktail, crab melt, and assorted fried seafood.  All good and reasonably priced considering the touristy location.  I hear breakfast is their specialty so I'll have to come back for that!
author: L H.

description: I always enjoy what I order here. The prices are a little high for what you get, but good food. On my last visit I got the grilled strawberry pancakes. Yum!
author: Kristina W.

description: The crab cake eggs Benedict are awesome.  The plate is huge and is enough food to share, my husband had corn beef hash and said it was ok.  I'm giving 4 stars based solely on my dish bc I can't wait to go back to get it.  It is touristy but when you have friends in town 2 birds one stone.
author: Brooke K.

description: Very friendly staff.  Delicious clam chowder and decent fish and chips.  Great service and quick sit down for the wharf.
author: Amy a.

description:
Hostess was excellent.  We were seated originally at the bar, but a table opened up quickly and she moved us without us asking.

Food was good, but pricey for what you get ($12 burger, $15 PoBoy, $1 for a soda refill).  Think you are paying for the location.

Service was average.  You have to fight your way to the lone unisex bathroom for the entire place.
author: Jim P.

description: Love it! I try to come for the clam chowder bread bowl whenever i am in town. It is a nice little place at pier 39 with good prices and good portions. Yeah, Boudin is like a block away but I like going with this place everytime. its a cant Miss, I will definitley be coming here on my next trip home!
author: Rafael L.

description:
i'm sad to see all the bad reviews b.c my friends and i had a pretty good time here. i'd give the place 3 1/2 stars. the birthday girl was craving some oysters, and when we got dropped off by our cab, the first thing we see is eagle cafe, breakfast, lunch, dinner, oyster bar. so we head there to check out their menu. saw that they had garlic fries, and we walk right in.

at first glance of the menu outside, it looks just like the menu of hash house here in sd and the one in vegas. same font, layout, and everything! we walk in and i look at the plates, same size dishes, exact plates, and my mouth is watering b.c i know i'm in for something good. 

we order 4 bloody marys, garlic fries and 12 fresh oysters to start off with. the fries and oysters came out first. and they were delish. the fries were finished in a quick second. and the oysters were pretty good. a splash of tabasco, and i'm all set! the other three ordered burgers which they thoroughly enjoyed and i wanted some clam chowder in a bread bowl. you can't come to the fisherman's wharf and not have some chowder in a bread bowl. now it wasn't amazing clam chowder, but it satisfied my hunger. i loved that they put it in a gigantic bowl, and had the chowder spilling over the bread, when you get a bread bowl, the inside of the bowl isn't all cut out, so you don't usually get much chowder, but this was perfect!

the only thing i didn't like was our plates constantly being taken away when we weren't quite finished with them. i believe there's still some food on that plate, and there's no way i'm going to let an oyster go to watse! the prices were a bit high or my blood, but you can't expect anything less when you have a great view of the wharf and alcatraz.
author: Pamela s.

description: My boyfriend and I randomly ended up here the other day while wandering around the city on a Sunday afternoon. It was a gorgeous day so we opted to sit outside at the bar top on the second floor and people watch. The clam chowder was pretty good here, served in either a bread bowl, bowl or cup. We also ordered a calamari which was really good! I recommend this place if you happen to be in Pier 39 and are looking for a place to hang out, have a beer and people watch.
author: Christina D.

description: Had a delicious Saturday brunch here - arrived close to noontime and they were still serving breakfast.
