I had the mushroom and jack cheese omelette which arrived on a boat sized plate filled with well seasoned house potatoes, four wedges of sourdough toast, and slices of orange and cantaloupe. (Note: egg whites may be substituted for an additional charge ~$2, choice of bread and fresh fruit vary depending on what's available.) Also indulged in a Bloody Mary flavored with Absolute Peppar - spicy and refreshing! Servers were all pleasant and very attentive without being bothersome. Being accustomed to the higher price ranges of food establishments around the wharf/downtown SF, the prices here were not shocking at all (my plate was ~$12, drink $7), and considering the gigantic portion size and quality of the food/drink, I found the meal to be an overall great value. Perhaps this may not be the most satisfying place to have lunch or dinner - after reading some of the previous reviews - but the breakfast/brunch menu earns a thumbs up from me! And I liked that amongst the hustle and bustle of other eateries at Pier 39, this was busy, but not overly crowded since it's up on the 2nd level away from all the tourist traffic down below.
author: Elaine W.

description: This place is awesome! Their crab melt is the best I've tasted in SF and the hospitality is more than welcoming. If you're looking for a chill spot or a romantic evening, I'd recommend Eagle Cafe.
author: Brenden L.

description: It's assumed that the prices in every eatery in Fisherman's Wharf are completely jacked but I'm not going to let them off easy because of it. I would really give the Eagle Cafe 2 1/2 stars. My grilled shrimp salad was good but it was just shrimp, lettuce, and dressing. That's it? For $19 throw a girl a crouton or something. My fiance's sandwich with seasoned fries was pretty good, but again the price issue...
author: Abby P.

description: I have been here several times - the portions were huge!  I could never finished them.  I love the breakfast omelettes - my fav is the California omelette.  The service was great and the view was stunning!  I was there on a nice warm day and got to sit outside to really enjoy the Cali weather.  I love their drinks - especially the margaritas!  A lot of ppl said how pricey things are - but this IS pier 39 San Francisco!  I think all the food places in this area are about the same.  So...just enjoy it :)
author: MissJ J.

description: Eagle Cafe had the best breakfast and mimosas that I've had in a long while.  Loved that it had a great view, being at Pier 39 and the service was awesome too.  Anytime that I'm ever in San Fran I'm absoutely hitting up Eagle Cafe.
author: Lisa B.

description: Horrendously, unspeakably, UNFORGIVABLY bad, in terms of service AND quality.  I have NEVER received such poor service, EVER, in all my years (...OK, maybe once...  See my review of "It's Delectable".  ...but that was a long time ago, and of a completely different type.  The Eagle Cafe is just pure INCOMPETENCE):  A SEVENTY-FIVE-minute wait for entrees, with nothing more than unfulfilled promises from our server that our food would be "right out" (never happened), and complete neglect from management, making no efforts whatsoever to put the situation right.  We ran out of time during our already extended lunch break, and just took our items to go.  And when we finally DID get them, they were of the absolute WORST quality.  A fucking JOKE.  Really.  For the prices they charge, they should be utterly ashamed of themselves.  Personally, if I were the manager, I would be embarrassed to offer such service.  This place should be CLOSED DOWN; the owners & managers made to hang their sorry heads in SHAME!!!  Save your money, and go find a quality place.  The Eagle Cafe doesn't give a rat's ass about you, or ANY of its customers.
author: Eric H.

description: Absolutely love this place.  I'm from the East Bay so yes we do go over to the City and do the tourist thing.  My husband and I do what we call "date day" and we absolutely love to go to the Eagle Cafe and order their raw oysters.  Nothing better than to order their raw oysters, along with a few Oyster Rockafellers (sp?).  Ambiance is nice and during football season it is nice to watch the games while we eat.  One more thing - their Bloody Mary's are simply the best.  Price is a bit high, but oh so worth it.  Service is usually good - not overly friendly, but good.
author: Karen Z.

description: What happened to my Eagle Cafe. The found memories of a restaurant that truly captured the essence of San Francisco. The oldest restaurant on Pier 39. They actually lifted the building and set it on top of the Pier so that they can build the parking area. The atmosphere was like cheers, everyone knew your name. Most that worked on the Pier would stop off at the Eagle for a drink and to socialize before going to random bars around the neighborhood after work. The portions were massive, but to be fare there still pretty big. I used to looooove the breakfast. Living near by I would come here every Sunday just for the breakfast. Lunch was good. Dinner was too. The Eagle really change from a few years back. I think its called Tin Fish at the Eagle or something. Now it has no character. It just blends in with all the other restaurants on the Pier. The food is good, they have more choices now. I don't eat there anymore but I'm not mad at them. Hey, its a business. They had to sell out in order to turn a profit. I'd probably do the same.
author: Christian H.
